title: Unlock Permanently Banned Accounts ReFormed Players
body:
I'm sure everyone in the community knows friends who has been toxic and inappropriate in their league games. Some of you may even know friends who have gotten banned for a week, 2 weeks or even permanently banned. Some of these players don't realize the harshness of the punishment riot can bring to your account.

Well, I happen to be that person. I was permanently banned for saying a bunch of stupid things that meant nothing to me at the time. I truly feel bad for the people that had to go through my behavior. I severely regret the hundreds of dollars I spent on the game only for it to go to waste. That's why I'm here to make a statement and tell anyone that exhibits toxic behavior to stop now, it will only get worse.

I feel like many people that have been permanently banned, didn't know the true punishment to behaving in such a way. I also feel that many perma-banned players have been reformed, myself included and want to continue playing League of Legends with their group of friends. I believe that Riot should unlock all permanently banned accounts starting fresh this new season. This will allow everyone to get a chance to reform and prove themselves on the Summoner's Rift.

Please consider unlocking permanently banned accounts this upcoming season. I'm sure the community will come together again.

From the [Tribunal FAQ](http://forums.na.leagueoflegends.com/board/showthread.php?t=2411284): 

>**Why can’t you give permanent banned players a second chance? You will receive a better player. **
Actually, this is the unfortunate problem. Allowing permanently banned players another chance is an extremely damaging cost. Do you know what the success rate of the Level 20 Challenge was? 5%. Do you know that for each person, they clearly outlined the toxic behaviors and had 1 on 1 conversations with the players to try to improve their behavior? These are players that were hand-picked by Player Support staff because they felt the pleas from these players were genuine. The success rate was still 5%. 

>Do you know how many games on average these players played? 100 games / month. When a permanently banned player fails to reform, they are creating miserable experiences for hundreds, maybe thousands of players a month. That's not a cheap cost or a low risk and we cannot consciously justify that, for the sake of the rest of our players.

I participated in the Tribunal back in the day and it was far from perfect. One major issue was that we'd often get cases from months back. Couple that with the fact that it was slow to process cases. Was the Tribunal helpful during its time? Yes. Would it still work today? In the form it was before it shut down most likely not.

>Second, they picked the wrong peoeple for said test. They picked them based on their "genuine pleas" how about picking those who spent a lot of money and time and actually achieved a good rank, lets say plat or higher. These are the true players who value their accounts and time spent.

Rank achieved and/or money spent do not always equal good behavior, and even back then those two did not exempt players from being held accountable for their behavior. If they truly valued their accounts and time spent then they wouldn't have consistently behaved poorly to the point where they lost their accounts, and then they wouldn't have had to go through the lv.20 challenge in the first place to try to redeem themselves. Even today people still try to use the "but I spent money on the game" excuse to justify their poor behavior to no avail, so that excuse didn't work back then and it certainly doesn't work now.

>Thirdly, @Prandine, we are human, not pieces of steel. We are flexible not always by-the-book. Maybe thats how you got the blue arbitur rank, but how about thinking about the community as a whole and not simply defending riot because that's how you became "successful."

I'm aware that we're human, and even I have my moments where I get frustrated and angry with people I play with/against. However, I simply yell and rage at the screen instead of in the chat to vent my frustrations. If more people did that or simply chose different outlets outside of the game to vent their frustrations then chances are we'd have less people getting punished for poor behavior (or at least for chat-related behavior anyways).

As for my Arbiter title I got it by being knowledgeable about things player behavior related and helping out in that area for so long. It's certainly not for defending Riot 24/7 as I certainly don't agree with everything they do, such as removing Dominion as a permanent game mode, but that's a topic for another thread.

First off: That's debatable. The threat of a permaban is a lot more real when you technically already had one.

Secondly: It wouldn't imply Riot "screwed up" because it's Riot's and **only** Riot's decision how many chances they are willing to give people. There's nothing to screw up here, it's their decision. They have to draw the line somewhere, and they will always have to draw it before somebody is reformed (otherwise they'd never permaban anybody).

But most importantly: If a season long ban would have been more applicable, then why would Riot not want to do season long bans? Less permabans = Less customers lost.

Lets not pretend that's an Apples to Apples comparison for today. The Level 20 challenge was at a time when it was significantly harder to earn a Permaban in the first place. The average permabanned player today would likely have received few hundred games of Chat Restrictions instead of a Permaban on the old system. Yes, the incentive to change was there, but the problems were much deeper rooted at the time of the challenge.

The Level 20 challenge needs to be redone, with players who are banned in the current system going through it. They can even raise the level cap to accommodate for the easier leveling that exists now, just to keep it fair. I'm confident that the success rate would be drastically better than 5%.

In response to the blue arbiters defending Riot:

First off, getting permabanned now is far more punishing than getting permabanned 6-7 years ago. Back then it was nothing to make a new account and get back the mere 50-ish champions and still be able to get all of the exclusive and rare skins back. If you get banned today... then damn you have around 140 champions to unlock and you have lost all of your old content that will likely never come back( like riot singed, pax jax, ufo corki, etc) People have a lot more to lose today compared to back then. With the chance to get back lost "treasures" in a sense, that would encourage and promote continued reform.

Second....Riot and the arbiters love to bring up the level 20 challenge, but here is the problem. That program was flawed and doomed from the start on Riot's end more than anything else.  I mean they hand picked players to represent the community instead of having some sort of program or filter to chose the real best possible candidates. This is would be like having a manager hire someone because they like them, not because they are the best possible person for the job. Anytime a person(s) are hand picked for something then it immediately adds subjectivity to the experiment over objectivity. They delude themselves into thinking they have the best of the best for the program. Riot's  "picks" failed and Riot wrongly assumed that if their picks had such a poor performance then the community as a while would have poor a performance.   The other major problem was the sample size.....holy crap was it small.  There is no way a sample size that small should be able to represent the community as a whole. Especially now that league has grown to over 100 million players+.  To give people some perspective as to how small and unfair the sample size was(compared to today).... Imagine I flipped a penny 200,000 times but only chose 10 flips to represent the out come.  The 10 flips from my sample were 8 heads and 2 tails....I will now conclude from my sample that a penny will land on heads 80% of the time.  Now imagine riot decided to pick 10 people out of 200,000 permabanned players to represent them and prove reform is possible and determine if others will get a chance to get their accounts back.  9 out of 10 fail and riot declares a 90% fail rate and scraps the program. That is a rough example to show you how skewed the sample size was compared to the amount of players today. 

Third..this will go more on the conspiracy side of things but some people (myself included after reading all i could find on the level 20 challenge) think Riot actually wanted it to fail and chose the cream of the crap to represent the community in hopes that it would. This way Riot can always go "sorry we tried" whenever the topic of un-banning permabanned accounts comes up. They will also make more money when most ( hey, league is an addicting game) make new accounts and buy RP for boosts and to get back their favorite skins and champions that were lost.

This idea is brought up on a semi-regular basis, Riot has commented on it before.  

Several years ago, Riot had such a program on an experimental basis whereby they gave permanently banned players one last chance on their account to reform.  The results were very easy to predict, An overwhelming majority of them were banned again within a matter of days or weeks or toxic behavior.  

Personally, I believe permanent bans are a waste of time in a free-to-play game where individuals can easily create or acquire new accounts.  A better solution to handle those that are perpetually toxic is an invisible, permanent mute.  The player doesn't know that they are muted, they can see their own chat, their friends can see their chat, but other players (not on their friends list) cannot see their chat, therefore they have no idea that they have been permamuted and thus the problem has been rectified.

I'm aware many are asking for another chance, but look at it from Riots point of view: they've already given the player multiple chances already to no avail, and if they give just anyone who asks another chance then what does that say about them as a company that tries to look out for its player-base? The line has to be drawn somewhere. While some players may genuinely be sorry for their actions and may in fact never have another punishment again if given the chance not everyone is like that sadly. Who's to say that some people asking for another chance are just claiming that they've reformed when they actually haven't? Riot's already been down that road before with the lv.20 challenge (which failed spectacularly btw) and it's not a chance they feel comfortable taking again, and given many of the forum posts I've read from banned players over the years I honestly don't blame them.

People are still free to make a new account and prove that they've reformed on that one (which some people have actually managed to do btw), but their old accounts are gone forever, as there has to be some lasting reminder of the potential consequences for consistently poor behavior. I'm aware that not everyone is comfortable spending time or money again on another account and that's their decision to make. I'm also aware that there are other game options besides LoL, and if people prefer those games more over LoL then more power to them. Riots behavioral standards are not for everyone, and there are plenty of other games out there with less strict rules on player behavior (whether that's good or bad depends on your point of view).

As far as Esports are concerned that's a completely separate team from the Player Behavior team. You said and I quote: 

> It is great to see people are giving up LOL and start playing Fortnite now (Well, at least they care about us). Last weekend during the LCS playoff, people chose to watch Fortnite (not even tournament) > LOL (500k vs 200k). Young teenagers choose to play the popular games (Like Fortnite, PUBG or New games in future), and then Riot doesn't care about the people who still playing LOL or want to play LOL.

What you didn't take into consideration was that the LCS match last weekend was for Quarterfinals, which that getting less views than say the Semifinals, the 3rd place match or even the Finals is to be expected. Also, whenever a new MOBA game comes out many people are quick to make the claim that it'll somehow be the "LoL killer", much how like many players were quick to make the claim that new MMOs would be the "WoW killer", neither of which ever ended up being true as both games still remain popular and played often by many players to this day. If Fortnite retains its popularity then good for them, but that doesn't necessarily mean that Riot won't care about its newcomer or veteran players if that does indeed happen.
